The Imperial College predictions have come from a group led by Prof Neil Ferguson who famously predicted 200,000 deaths in the UK from nvCJD on the heels of the Mad Cow Disease outbreak. There have been 177 deaths to date. I think what this demonstrates is that the quality of the predictions made by a model is unlikely to exceed the quality of the inputs. In that case the mechanism of spread of the disease seems to have been totally misunderstood.


Something similar might also be happening with Covid-19. There are at least two possible confounding factors. One was suggested by a small US study looking for antibodies which, while questionable in its design, suggests that the number of people who have contracted the infection may exceed the reported number by a factor of 50-85 times. If correct, this would indicate that the overwhelming majority of Covid-19 infections are mild and that it is far more infectious than present figures suggest. A second factor is the evident genetic instability of this virus. Multiple mutations have already be observed and a study in Iceland which sampled 5% of the population found 40 variants.


Given that a successful virus spreads as much as possible, selection pressure favours less harmful viruses with higher infectivity. This is thought to be what happened in the case of the first SARS coronavirus: it mutated away from pathogenicity and took itself out of the equation as a serious pathogen. The high rate of mutations might also point to why some areas are seeing different characteristics of the infection. Here's hoping! Generally, what this whole episode is showing is that we don't really have a good idea yet of what's going on and we have to be ready to update the models frequently.

Hey Hank! Quick question. As I understand it, this virus will continue to spread until either:

(1) we hit sufficient herd immunity to drop Ro below 1.0, at which point the virus will start to decline, or

(2) we develop a vaccine.

It seems like experts predominantly agree that option 1 will happen before option 2. If this is true, then the number of total infected individuals will be about the same regardless of what measures we take. All we can affect is who is infected, and how long it takes to reach the necessary level of herd immunity. The latter is what experts mean when they say “flatten the curve.” If we want to avoid deaths, we should:

(1) keep infections below the level that would overwhelm hospitals, and

(2) try to keep susceptible people from getting sick.

If this is true, wouldn’t the best solution be to allow non-susceptible people to interact as much as possible as long as we stay below an amount that would overwhelm hospitals? It seems like many governments are trying to distance far beyond this point - unless they’re willing to do so for over a year for a vaccine, I think this will end up killing more people in the long run. By having overly-extensive distancing, you force non-susceptible people to behave like susceptible people, which gives them a roughly equal chance to contract the disease. If you loosen restrictions, non-susceptible can be less careful and take up more of the necessary infections.

Just curious as to your thoughts. This seems to be pretty much the opposite of most discourse I hear, which says that non-susceptible people that aren’t distancing aggressively are irresponsible and hazardous.

Yay, the models were wrong! Because they changed behaviour! Except... how has the behavioural change altered anything?
Is it a flattening to allow for more ventilators to be ready? Vents with a ~20% recovery rate when used? That doesn't cause a mortality reduction of 15x.
Is it because the virus is expected to be eliminated with only a fraction of the population exposed? No, that's not going to happen with animal reservoirs.
Is it because long-term hygiene improvements reduce the percentage required for herd immunity? If this is done really well, maybe herd immunity only requires 40% exposure rather than 60%.
Is it because of improved treatment protocols? Maybe, but there have been precious few confirmed improvements. Hydroxychloroquine is still being argued about. Ibuprofen is known to be harmful... well, maybe.
Or is it because the models were built on shaky assumptions, and they still are, and science is a political football?

It sucks that it takes so long for SciShow to upload these videos. It's only been 3 weeks, but in the US, we have already surpassed 74,000 deaths. At the time of filming, I think the estimated fatality rate was still at 2-3%, so that might be why those models predicted smaller numbers.
Here are more factors that need to be considered for more accurate modeling:

- It typically takes 10 days to show symptoms
- Current estimates put asymptomatic carriers at a range between 20% and 80% of all cases, most of these never are tested
- The duration that someone with it is infectious


There are more robust models than the SIR model which take all of that into account, but that data needs to be known to a high degree of certainty in order to create a better model. Alternate models include SEIR(susceptible, exposed, infected, recovered) and SEYAR(susceptible, exposed, symptomatic, asymptomatic and recovered). These can more accurately model the outbreak, and get a better estimate of R-o. Unfortunately, with these more robust models, it's looking like this disease is about as bad as it can get. Some newer models are showing that the R-o of COVID-19 is closer to that of Measles. Measles is the most infectious disease we know of, with an R-o of 12-18. I saw one model that puts COVID-19 R-o at a median of 14. Obviously, it should be taken with a grain of salt, but how high that number is really depends on how many asymptomatic and presymptomatic carriers there really are. Highly accurate serological tests are the only way we can really get that data.

One recent paper for reference: https://www.medrxiv.org/content/10.1101/2020.03.18.20037994v3.full.pdf
It is a pre-print, so again, grain of salt.

Small correction: R0 is generally regarded as the "basic reproductive number" of an disease in a susceptible population *that does not take any special protective measures*, so R0 doesn't change because of the measures taken. The effective reproduction number "R" (without the naught/zero) does reflect the measures taken, like vaccinations or social distancing.
